the drink...wine was moderately priced...but i was still confused about a kamakazi for freaken $8.30....just thought the price was so odd....the steak...i read all this talk about prime aged steak in the post..but it was far from well aged...the size was bigger then norm compared to most restaurants..but i was pretty disappointed in the quality....a nice well aged steak should be eaten rare because it's dry aged which takes lot of the moisture out from the steak....what i got here was a fleshy slimy piece of carcass...drowning in butter...the twice cooked potato was probably my favorite part of the meal..it was half a baked potato....for $7..i was thinking a whole potato..but not at bobo's....chocolate cheesecake fondue...the variety of cookies for dipping seemed a little stale...it wasn't crispy...it was bit rubbery...the fondue was odd but tasteful...

just a pointer...if you are going to get a steak here...i would suggest sticking to a filet mignon (no bone)...and probably medium...this poor quality of steak should not be eaten rare...it is too slimy and fleshy...and not properly aged...i found harris' to be much superior quality..
author: Hen A.

description: Great obscure spot.  We took my Mom and dad here for their birthdays.  Excellent service and excellent food.  The fresh bead they bring out is amazing.  We got the fillet no bone in and shared sides.  The Mac n cheese, the twice baked potato, brussel sprouts and greens were also excellent.  Everyone had a great time.  Glad I finally made it there.
author: Kirsten M.

description: Unique dining place with very romantic atmosphere... Love the food especially the fillet mignon with bone... Appetizers are delicious as well...the clams and shrimps are my favorite!!!
author: Nathalie H.

description:
This place happened to be open on Cristmas eve.... we went here after getting turned away at Suppenkuch. 

My steak was really good but the sides were just so so. This place is WAY overpriced and everything comes a la cart. 
For the price I would much rather go to The Brazen head or Bix.

If your work is paying or if you get taken here on a date ... enojy .. otherwise ... seek steak elsewhere.
author: Jeremy R.

description:
Way over priced for quality of food & service.  

Cocktails are $12--the most I've ever paid for one in the city--and the Martini glass certainly wasn't filled up all the way.

This is yet another restaurant where you are charged an additional $8 per side if you want anything to go with your crab or steak (we went for the crab).  Rather than get a side, my boyfriend and I opted for the ahi tuna appetizer ($14), which had very skimpy cuts of tuna, which we could barely taste.

I dined late Friday night, 10/12/07, with eight other friends for a surprise birthday dinner.  Granted, we had a large party, but it should not have taken 30 minutes for the bread to arrive.  We were seated at 8:45 and were starving.

The only redeeming quality of this overpriced restaurant is the complimentary valet.  Several of my friends tried to find parking on their own and were searching for a solid 45 minutes.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
THE BEST steak I have ever eaten in my life.  Perfectly cooked and seasoned on the outside, perfectly red and raw on the inside!  I think I might have dreamt about it last night.  
The wine was great too, plus next time we will bring our own since their corkage fee is only $15.  
Our server, Amber was wonderful.  Perfect amount of attentiveness, not too much, not too little. We got the crab crostini too which was good but I could live without everything else but the STEAK! did I mention it was THE BEST STEAK EVER????

My taste buds loved me last night.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Came here for dinner tonight.  Overall, the food was pretty good.

We started with the lobster bisque and the tuna appetizer.  Both good.  I liked the tuna more.  But the lobster bisque had at least two claw pieces in it.  and I think its more like the consistency of a split pea soup.

We decided to share the porterhouse and one whole crab.  That, people, was just the right amount of food.  The porterhouse was fantastic.  Seared on the outside, pink on the inside.   so tender, that you barely need to chew.  The sauce it came in was tasty too.  One of the tastiest piece of meat I have ever had.  The only weird part about it was that, it was served with filet and the NY apart.  I was kinda hoping they would be cooked as one whole piece.  

The crab, ladies and gentlemen, is in one piece, all the claws and legs are still attached to the body.  The only part that is detached is the top shell.  You have to work for every piece of meat you get out of the crab.  I am going to recommend that you dip the crab meat back on the garlic butter left on the skillet, otherwise, I thought it was a little dry.  

The only thing i didnt really enjoy was the bread.  It looked like it would be warmer and softer, but it was rather hard, cold and dry.  We only took a few bites out of that.

We decided to skip dessert, since we were so close to Swensen's, we had ice cream there instead.
author: Janet S.

description:
The first time I went to boboquivaris, my (ex)boyfriend had taken me. 

He was a ladies man through and through. Which was the bane of our existence together as a couple. Nonetheless everywhere we went there was a girl her knew or well probably slept with. So why would this place be any different? Well it wasn't and well he "knew" the waitress.  So you see this romantic dinner ended up being horribly awkward. 

But even though the situation was well, less than appetizing, I do have to say that the dinner was outstanding. That being said...

Probably the only good thing to come out of the relationship was this introduction to this restaurant - which is now, my all time favorite steak house. 

The food here is beyond good, it's heavenly. Almost sinful. (If you can get over the horrid decor. )

If you go here you MUST have the crab and steak! Try the crab salad or crab cakes to start, also i must say that the wasabi tuna tar tar/ sashimi was delicious. 

But don't forget to order the bone in filet mignon. You won't be sorry, in fact, you'll be sorry if you don't order it. 

It is THE most succulent, juicy, flavorful steak i've ever eaten! 

Hands down, best place for a steak in San Francisco!
author: California G.

description:
Now I definitely consider myself a steak aficionado, I have been to steak houses far and wide. This steak (the bone-in filet) is by far one of the best steaks I have ever head. The restaurant itself has wonderful service, and an excellent wine list. Oh yes, and the crab is amazing too.


Don't expect to go here and get a deal though, it will definitely cost you a pretty penny, but is worth every single cent. This is a steak that I crave/dream about, yummmmm I want one now please.
author: Tamara R.

description:
Hidden gem comes to mind. I have visited many types of steakhouses in the Bay Area and about 4 years ago I heard about Bobo's (short for Bobquivari's). I was hesitant to try something different and cheat on Morton's Steakhouse and their signature Cajun Rib-Eye. BUT, I have to tell you, it was worth sneaking behind their back and grabbing a Bone-in-Filet at Bobo's - their signature dish. Very delicious, juicy, right balance of fat and lean throughout the steak. 

Beyond the steaks, Bobo's side dishes are fantastic.  The Swiss Chard, Bermuda Onion Rings, and Twice Baked Potatoe are the perfect match with the Bone-in-Filet. And don't forget the amazing Tuna Carpaccio as an appetizer.

The wine selection is also great. One thing I noticed was the prices. The overall price of the bottles was way below par compared to other steakhouses. 

Overall, great value, one of a kind steakhouse. I highly recommend it! Enjoy.
author: Kesh P.

description: I've been here a couple of times before but this is my first review on Yelp for them.  We had our latest dinner club here and we had a great time.  The wine was great and the meal was excellent without being too over the top expensive like many steak places are.  The bread to being with was great and fluffly.  The appetizers and the sides were very good and there was a lot of food over the entire course of the meal but we didn't feel too full until dessert came in which we had to pass on.  My only complaint was that we sat on the second floor in the room with striped drapes hanging down and it felt like the room was moving and it wasn't just the wine talking because others in my group felt the same.
author: Blake B.

description:
First impression?  Totally UNIMPRESSED with the ambiance.  It's garish.  It's loud (both visually and phonically due to the very low ceilings and tight quarters on the first floor).  We also stood there for several minutes, waiting to be seated for our reservation before anyone even acknowledged us.  I wasn't encouraged.

We finally sat down.  The service was a little clumsy, but endearing coming from our newly employed Irish waitress.  Once her jitters subsided, the service was gracious, timely and spot on.

Then came dinner.  I don't think I've ever cried into a plate of food before.  There were nothing but tears of joy and appreciation for the remains of that cow that now sat in front of me, served by a restaurant that was mere steps away from my house.  

A bit of trivia:  They are one of only three restaurants in the country who dry age their steak for over 21 days...and none on the west coast other than Bobo's. 

So here is a run down of my full meal:  
-Crab cakes and caesar salad
-New York bone-in
-Twice baked potato, and sauteed spinach
-Raspberry panna cotta
-Chocolate mousse dunce cones

**NOTE:  DO NOT miss the dunce cap ice cream cones served upside down on your plate, filled with chocolate moose and chocolate sauce.  For something lighter but absolutely delicious and refreshing, get the raspberry panna cotta with espresso bean foam.

The only downside was that we were so PAINFULLY full once we got home that all we could do was lay on our couch, unbutton our pants, and drift off into a miserable, fitful nap fraught with meat sweats and demonic dreams of eating more steak.  

I think about this meal all the time, and can't wait to go back to experience the happiness it brought me.  Truly a remarkable steak.  I'll never eat a steak at Izzy's again (the potatoes and creamed spinach, maybe.  But never a steak).
author: Lauren S.

description: Texans approve of the bone-in filet. Yummy ya'all!!
author: C W.

description:
4 stars if you eat steak.  2 stars if you don't.  
BF had the filet mignon bone-in and said it was his second-favorite steak in the city (next to Morton's, and beating many other similarly-priced steakhouses).       
But for non-steak-eaters, everything else is too salty or overly seasoned - the crab, the veggie sides, the salad.  
Don't come here for ambiance, wine selection, or anything else for that matter...except steak.
author: Jeanne J.

description:
By far my fav place to date for a nice and splurgeful evening. 
If you like crab, this is the place to go to. If you love steak, this is the place to go to. 
We had the crab and shrimp appetizer. The crab was perfect, alongside the garlic and caper butter - YUMO!
The filet in bone was perfectly cooked, and seasoned. 
The twice baked potatoes, sweet potatoes, brussel sprout side dishes were very tastey too. 
The bread, which seemd to be drenched in olive oil was delic!
Their drink menu was good. Their Moscow Mojito, and their Toasted Hazelnut drink was mouthwatering.
author: J O.

description: My husband took me here the night he purposed to me! We sat in a very romantic nook and had one of the best steaks! Everything was excellent! We will definitely be back!
author: Sammy D.

description:
steak, mussels, and bread alone give it 5 stars.  the sides are just ok.  the crab, despite its top billing, is just ok.  

bone in filet is like butter.  i had the new york bone in as well, which i liked because it has a bit more texture than the filet, but you can't go wrong either way.
author: Oliver C.

description:
We were at Bobo's on Saturday night.  Made the reservation on Open Table a few days in advance.  We were looking soooooooo forward to eating at this steak house, however we were dissapointed.  For one, had to wait for one half hour to be seated.  Two, I ordered the petit filet and it was SO SMALL!  Myhusband ordered the porterhouse, and what a dissapointment!  He was telling all his friends how big this thing was and how it was prepared and cooked...  I was teasing him about how I didn't believe it was going to finish it... well, he ordered it, it arrived and all four of us just looked at it.  It was flat, yes it was cut in two, but did not at all look like the picture.  Very small.  I mean for $70.00!  Totally NOT worth that price for sure!
My petit filet looked like a mashed hamburger!  Kids meal size if that!  What I will say is the flavor of both steaks was good...  but the size and portion was a joke.  I felt like we were "ripped off!"  
The couple we were with, were happy with their steaks, bone in filet..  but with our two steaks being so small and "not like the picture" and expensive, it put a damper on our entire dining experience.  
We brought a bottle of wine and the corkage fee is $15.00.   Our waiter said we wouldn't have to pay because we had waited so long for our table.
All in all... would I go back again?  No.  It was OK.  Maybe I would sit at the bar and have a drink ... maybe.... 
Based on our experience here that evening for all four of us, we decided we would NOT reccomend this place.  It's OK.
But we were VERY dissapointed.  Money is too hard to earn these days and for a steak that is 70.00 and one that is 30.00 that looks like a kids meal....  I expect more!
Totally not worth it.  I would go to Izzy's anyday.
We just wanted to try something other than the Ruth Chris, Morton's, Harris experience.    So we strayed from the norm.... and now we know.
author: Demery D.

description: I have been here several times now and NEVER been disappointed.  Made a reservation at 10pm for 10:30 and they had no problem.  After we finished the FABULOUS dinner (try the hamachi carpaccio for an app) we sat at the bar while they closed down.  Great bartenders and great music.  We will definitely be back!!!!
author: K E.

description: The meat was cooked to perfection and the service was great but the sauce was a little too oily and over salted. Also, it's a little too expensive for what ye got.
author: Alice S.

description:
Finally tried this place after several (emphatic!) recommendations from a co-worker. We had a group of 6 and were seated in a booth on the 1st floor. The fit was a bit snug, but the space is pretty nice. The food:
1. Appetizers were all very well done and included - crab/salmon crostini, tomato salad w/ burrata, and the burrata w/ salt - all delicious!
2. Mussels/shrimp/crab on the iron skillet - the table was pretty crowded by then, but all 3 were super tasty - and worth the buttery fingered mess.
3. My entree - I opted for the NY strip. One of the best steaks I've every had! Will try the bone-in filet next time.

We had vegetarians in the group (4 stars instead of 5 for not even offering 1 veggie option - this is the bay area for goodness sakes), so we ordered all the sides. The onion rings and swiss chard were particularly tasty. The fluffy loaf of bread with garlic butter in the center was very (very) quickly dispatched. So good! For dessert, we had the chocolate bomb (decent), cheesecake (good), pastichio panna cotta (great!). Everything at Bobo's is so well done, and they have complementary valet to boot! Can't beat that!
author: Eme L.

description:
I soon found out I couldn't order lasagna here ... just crab and steak and a buttered sole the chef was forced to put on the menu at gunpoint by an enraged anti-meat eater.  I found out that there are only two filet mignon's on a cow with the bone-in according to the server.  Okay you got a deal sister, just make sure you give me the filet on the left side of the cow, kay??

I wasn't too sure I ended up getting the one on the left side.  I got this filet with bone-in for 39 clams.  It came out juicy, perfectly cooked not heavily seasoned.  For a meat eater it was satisfying.  Honestly though, I can't sit here and tell you I was blown away.    I've had more excitement watching Jerry Springer than eating the steak here and that show makes me ill.  

I ordered a twice baked potato on the side and was expecting a fluffed up potato with all the fixin's inside of it.  What I got was a submarine looking potato that literally looked like they gutted the potato, mashed it up with chives, sour cream and butter, stuck it back in the skin, and baked it again.  Realization time; probably why they called it twice baked potato.... either way I didn't care for the concept or the end result.

For a petit filet mignon the server informed us the portion was 5 ounces.  Should've clarified that because my guests were still hungry.  I think the server meant 5 ounces before cooking because it seriously looked like 3 ounces to me (after cooking became smaller than a deck of cards).  I could just here the guests mumble under their breath "ah shit, should've gone bigger."  Yes, yes ... I'm sure Katie Holmes thinks the same thing...

The bread was okay... a little olive oil, some olives and re-baked sourdough bread.  (Yawn).  

Wine prices were their usual 100% mark-up.  We diverted that catastrophe by bringing our own champagne and Bordeaux.  Complimentary valet was a nice touch but not enough to make me want to return.  

For the price, I think Boboquivari's is a bit on the high end when considering what you get.  For my money, Bob's on California continues to reign the steak title.
author: Bill P.

description:
It's unfortunate that the first impression that you'll have of this establishment consists of creepy clowns and an arrogant hostess with a lack of social skills. I wish I could say the food made up for the way that my family and I were treated upon our arrival, but it did not. I'll begin with the experience with the hostess then move on to the food, because I believe the former should be enough for you to make up your mind about coming to this restaurant. 

Upon arriving on time for our reservation, we were met with the smug hostess who informed us that our table was still not ready. That was strike one. After waiting ten minutes she curtly told my mother that she and the rest of my family were in the way of the waiters, and that we needed to move. Strike 2. Then on our way up the stairs to our table that was finally prepared well past the time of our reservation, she had the gall to openly ask "what was she looking at" as my mother walked by, while making arm gestures that made me question whether or not she had Parkinson's. She said this not once, but four times for our entire party to hear. And there was strike 3. If I wanted to get  bossed around by some bitch with a false sense of superiority and six inch heels I would have called a dominatrix. And after seeing other reviews, its blatantly obvious that the restaurant has had complains about her before. The only possible explanation that I can see for this woman to still have her job is a flagrant case of nepotism. 

Now for the food (just in case for some reason you still would like to come here.) I cannot deny that the Bone-In Fillet I ordered was good. Very good. It was tender, cooked well, and seasoned perfectly. However, it wasn't the best steak I've ever had and that is exactly what it would have to be in order for me to recommend anyone to come here. For the prices, there is no doubt that you can get a steak that is just as good, if not better, and still receive great service.
author: Josh J.

description:
Let me preface this by saying I went here to break the fast after this year's Yom Kippur.  This is good and bad.  I could have been eating old triscuits out of a paper bag and probably given it 5 stars.  I figured, what better way to break a fast though than gorging myself on delicious meat.

To sum it up, I broke my fast with:
1) A big iron pan of shrimp
2)A great appetizer consisting of a mozzarella/marscapone mix and fresh heirloom tomatoes
3)A huge bone-in New York steak that was quite literally one of the best I have ever consumed
4)2 twice-baked potatoes
5)A plate of swiss chard (I never knew swiss chard could be this good)
6)A kir-Royal sherbet.  For those that don't know Kir Royal is a divinely inspired cocktail consisting of Chamord and Champaign.   Perfect for any celebration.  Now it exists in sherbet form and it is amazing.

The only possible downside is that the decor looks like the interior of a circus tent but I thought that was actually kind of cool.  

Oh yeah and don't look at the bill.  Just assume you will spend a lot and don't ruin the great experience by worrying about it.
author: adam b.

description:
We liked this place! I had the bone-in filet and twice baked potato. I had to send the steak back as it was underdone, but it was one of the best steaks I have had. The potato was fantastic. My wife had a salad with crab and the twice baked potato. No complaints.

Service was excellent. Our waitress, Jen, was helpful, attentive and personable. The decor is not my taste, but we liked that the restaurant was divided into smaller spaces, so it was quiet.
author: Dave H.

description:
Pluses - free valet parking. Good cocktails, good service, great meat.

Minuses - a little dark - hard to read the menu, the portion size for sides - small for $10, you get 1/2 a stuffed potato?????? Chard wonderful, but again not much of it.
Had the fish carpaccio - wonderful, but not enough to share, could use some crackers/bread to go with it. There was some nice garlic bread for the whole table.

Good pacing with the food, no rush, and we were all having a good time.

A little pricey. we brought our own wine $15 corkage, shared a starter and 2 sides, and no dessert - $80 per person,
author: Elaine T.

description: The bone-in filet is the best steak I've ever had...twice.  The family style of the sides and appetizers makes the meal more enjoyable with sharing the goods.  The service is great and not overly attentive.  The decor is a little fun, tasteful, and at a few tables even a little intimate, though the upstairs can get a bit cramped.  Eat here.
author: Mike B.

description: Best meal I've had in a long time. And I love to eat. Was debating between a famous seafood place and a famous steak place while in SF for an overnight mini-vacay.... Found Bobo's and they have ruined prime rib dining for every other place I've been. For two people, we ordered the combination appetizer which was served on a sizzling platter filled with plenty of mussels, meaty crab legs, and just the perfect amount of shrimp (they could've easily used shrimp as "filler" but the other two portions were provided generously). We split the bone-in prime rib, medium rare, and it was so soft and flavorful, not too salty or chewy. Perfect texture. Even the mixed drinks were great. I would go there again. Definitely!
author: Harmony N.

description:
went here for a bachelor party dinner.

Service was great (and attractive ladies to boot)
Steak was great!  we had the bone-in filet.  But the best was the crab, shrimp app for the table.  
It was definitely a good special occasion spot.  Ended up being pricey, but worth it I think.
author: Aaron D.

description:
*********** 3 1/2 ********** to be exact
This was my chosen restaurant for D-Day...dreaded 29!!

I started with their Romaine Wedge Salad with tomatoes, 2 avocado slices, onions and EVOO...i was a bit disappointed to see cherry tomatoes instead of tomato slices.  The bread was too oily/buttered up for me and I don't care for olives on my bread.  HOWEVER, when the Petite Filet came juicy and cooked to Med. Rare perfection I was a happy camper...Now, they say the petite filet is 5 ounces but I wonder if that means 5 ounces before cooking cuz cooked it looked like 3 ounces cooked.  The DEFINITE WINNER was the bone-in filet mignon...that piece of meat was StupendouslyDeliciouslyFreaking Good...if I do return it will be for that specific cut ONLY!!

The service was very good, our group might have been a little too rambunctious since this annoyed blonde chick kept looking back at us...whatever she had up her ass was obviously not being helped by our laughter...anyway...we brought a bottle of champagne and a bottle of Bordeaux to dinner and so a $15 corkage fee applied for each...overall it was a decent experience but somehow I prefer Bob's steaks over Bobo's...
author: Karen B.

description: My friends and I were in SF this past weekend and happened to stumble upon this place.  I was beyond pleased with my meal.  I've been to several steakhouses over the years including Flemings but Bobo's had the best steak hands down!!  Don't even look at the menu, the manager told us that 95% of the people who come there order the same thing, which is the Bone-In Filet Mignon with a side of the twice baked potato.  This was the juiciest most flavorful steak I've ever had.  Outside of the food, the ambiance was incredible, I loved the layout and decor of the restaurant.  Expect to be there a while, everything is slow cooked so we were there for about 2 hours.  You must stop in if you are in SF I promise you won't be disappointed!!!
author: Amit S.

description:
Very good steak.

My girlfriend took me here for my birthday.  The restaurant is a nice little sanctuary of clowns on Lombard (the nice kind of clowns, not the scary kind).  It's surprisingly romantic.

We ordered the porterhouse for 2 and it came prepared unlike anything I had ever seen before.  The strip and the filet were presented separately off the bone so it looked like two separate steaks.  The strip was very flavorful and the filet was very tender.  The only thing that was a little strange was that both steaks were drenched in some kind of sauce.  Unusual for a steak-steak place.
author: howie f.

description:
In terms of food, this place would get 3 1/2 stars. The way the steak is cooked, you really have to like it that way. I ordered the Porterhouse which was only 15oz. But I guess they could get away with it with all the butter it was cooked with. The initial bite was very juicy and was good. But as I continued to eat the steak, it got a bit more rich, a bit more salty, and the char was really starting to kick in. I ordered the steak with the baked yams with brown sugar. It was good the first couple of bites, but then you start to realize how much brown sugar they actually put in it. The best part of the night was probably the portobello mushrooms. The italian cheesecake was good too. Usually cheesecake for me is too rich, but it was nicely light,  but the raspberry was too sweet. Waaaay too sweet. 

It started out well, it really did. The bread was magnificent, (take a little olive oil off) which was drenched in olive oil but was very crispy on the crusts. Very good. But then it went downhill, waaaay downhill. The lobster soup was real good though. Chunks of lobster at the bottom  and a hint of curry as a base.

The hostess was VERY humble and nice. I haven't been around a host or hostess who was that intriguing. But our waiter, DANIEL, was not very  friendly at all. He took our order but only came back to check on us once. He re-filled everyone else's cup of water in the room (top floor) except ours. He checked on everyone else at least twice. Not personable at all.

And what really killed the rating, was the short, bald bus boy. He was incredibly RUDE! I haven't faced that much rudeness from someone in a restaurant since Zazil. He was incredibly pushy, trying to take our dishes out of the way while we were still scooping food off of it. Sure there wasn't much left, but there was food left. And when we would ask him something, we wouldn't be given the opportunity to finish our question. He'd interrupt "wait a minute, wait a minute" until he was ready to accomodate us. I guess we were an inconvenience to him. The first time I thought, that was a bit rude but understandable if he was really busy. But he did it THREE times and it was just infuriating. If I wasn't at dinner with my boss, I would've went off on him and told him to shove something where it hurts. 

The food alone receives 3 1/2 stars, the hostess bumps it up to 4 stars. But the service from DANIEL and the SHORT, STUBBY, BALD BUS BOY knocks this place down to 1 star. 

Horrible service, good food, if you're looking for a heart attack. 

Would I come back? As long as Daniel and the short stubby bald bus boy are working there, NO
author: Calvin L.

description:
My husband and I were so disappointed.  
We loved their appetizer Mussels but his steak and my crab were both totally over cooked.  Their side dished were pretty good though - mushrooms & potatoes.
Their service was OK, although we had to ask for water several times before they actually brought a carafe to us.
author: Spoon K.

description:
if you're like me and get full easily [and tend to fill up on the pre-meal bread], the petite filet mignon is the perfect portion. i asked for it with the sauce on the side and ended up not using it because the filet itself is oozing with flavor. 

i also got to try the crab and seriously, you have gotta try the sauce and crab...stuff [?] that collects in the dish it comes on. take some of their heavenly olive-oil-drizzled bread and dip it in this crab sauce...and voila. food coma in no time. 

it's nice that they have valet parking here, but the one time i came here, there was only one person working and she must have been new because we had to wait almost 15 minutes for our car and ended up grabbing ours ourselves after we saw that she had scratched BOTH SIDES of the person before us' car.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I'm noticing a lot of high ratings for this place and I'm in awe as to why. This place is retched! Not to mention tacky, uninviting, and poorly serviced. Oh and the name? GROSS...

I had the unfortunate experience of visiting this place with some dork with donned a faux-hawk (yes, poor me), his wonky uncle, and his uncle's mistress. How weird!!?? Upon my arrival I was approached by the hostess in a very strange/uncomfortable manner. When I told her I was meeting people she looked me as though she had no idea what I had said. I soon got over this. But shortly thereafter I noticed that the staff was really attentive to the men. Not only asking them to order first, but almost waiting to see if they would order for us ladies. Ew.

I order a petite fillet...not hard to screw up, right? Well if you are looking for botched beef, Bobo's is your place. I requested that my meat be cooked medium. Hmm too bad it was close to well done! The quality of the meat was horrific. My side dish of cauliflower was uneventful and the wine was not so good. Oh, God, I cannot get over the red walls, tacky photos and the patrons. Most of those eating at Bobo's were trying really hard to be in the culinary know. This place sucks. The only redeeming quality was the dessert. However I was with a group of unfortunate individuals who ordered  EVERY DESSERT ON THE MENU (oh the embarrassment). Desserts were good, hence the two star rating. 

One can certainly find better steak in San Francisco. This place is a joke and anything owned by the owners of the Stinking Rose should be a sign to steer clear.
author: candace a.

description:
This was my second times at Bobo and I was looking forward to an amazing meal, and yes, the food met our expectations in every way.  For starters, we had the lobster crostini which was delicious & the crab which was very fresh.  For entree, had the bone-in filet and it is by far the best steak I ever had.  For sides, our table order the cauliflower, twice-baked potatoes, and portabella mushrooms. All were delicious and exceeded expectations.  For desert, the chocolate bomb and mango panna cotta were delicious.

However, the reason I'm giving them 3 stars is due to the poor service.  We felt rush and the server seem disinterested in serving our table. Other than asking for our order, I doubt if he asked us or said anything else.  When posed a question, he simply asked with a yes, or no, or a head nod.  (ie. which wine would you recommend?  He pointed to one on the wine list and said, this one is good.  He didn't even ask if we were interested in red or white).    For the price of the meal and the type of restaurant, I would have expected better service.  Even at McDonald, I would have been treated better.

PS. We were there for a business dinner and looked the part...hint hint hint....unlimited tab, but with the poor service we just felt like eating and going.  bah humbug.
author: Christina C.

description:
Reservations for 915pm. I scored parking right on Vaness. The entrance is a bit akward as there wasn't much standing room. We kept bumping shoulders with the waiters walking around.

Ambiance - Jester-like, a lot of red/white zig zag cloth walls, a lot of those old school circus dolls.  

Service - Excellent, not intrusive. 

Food - BONE-IN FILET MIGNON was TASTY!!!! ($39). I got the petite Filet Mignon at medium rare.  I think my first choice would be the Bone-in Filet.  

Bread- Loved the toasty garlic/olive bread. 
Zucchini Fritti - Fried. Nothing special.  This side was separate from the entree.  
Portabello Mushroom - It wasn't whole but diced up pieces with capers.  I liked it. 
Crabcakes - Fried item. Why do they make so much FRIED foods?? I think I would of liked it more if it wasn't fried but seared.  The crabs definitely tasted fresh.  I enjoyed the cranberry bits. It was either flavored with balsamic vinegar or soy sauce!

NO dessert.

Wine - We got the Cab from Stullburger (?) Vineyards.  


I think I like Ruth Chris's Steakhouse more than this place.  I'll need to write up a list of reviews for steakhouses in SF!
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Okay the reason that I gave them 3 stars is because of their service... Food is good but the service is always slow (there is always one server on each floor) and the servers can't attend to you in timely manner because they have way too many tables than they can handle. It is a good place to go as long as you are prepared to spend 3 to 4 hours for your dinner.
Also their dessert selection is very poor and boring..
author: Seda M.

description:
Went there for a retirment party not knowing what to expect.  I'll start with the bar.  It's tiny but the bartender was awesome.  It was a very busy night and she had it all under control.  She made me some fantastic lemon drops, kinda tart, loved them!

As for dinner, although I read reviews that said order the steak, I decided to order the crab because I'm such a seafood lover.  Big mistake on my part.  I assumed that the crab would be cracked and ready to go.  Instead it came out on the plate fully assembled looking like it could crawl off at any moment.  After my shock settled I did notice that the main body had been detached and then set back down on top of the rest of it, but still very intimidating.  I have to say I was a total wimp and could not handle all the cracking and squirting.  I didn't end up eating much of it, but what little I had was tasty.  I also had the opportunity to try a bite of steak and it was delish!  The sides were yummy too.  All in all it was great, minus my crab issue.  I will be back for more lemon drops and dinner; only this time I'm having a big slab of red meat, served rare of course!
author: Jennifer W.

description: Extremely delicious food and great service. The yellow tail carpaccio is truly orgasmic with the roasted garlic loaf...mmm mm heaven!!! What an amazing appetizer!  I had the surf & turf as well as mussels for the main course with a side of twice baked potato. I split it with my boyfriend. The portions were more than enough. I also had the blood orange sorbet in a waffle cone for dessert. A bit too sweet for me but was great! We were in town for the weekend and my boyfriend left his hat at the table. They mailed the hat to us free of charge.
author: Latoya H.

description: Amazing, eat there every time my dad comes to town to visit me - once or twice a month! The seafood is to die for. Went last week and the mussels were HUGE. We mentioned it to the server and he said they had just switched seafood companies and they have been getting a lot of compliments. If you want your food to OOOH and AWWW you, GO BOBO!
author: Jaclynn F.

description:
I really don't understand all the positive reviews this place gets.  My wife and I went here tonight after reading the reviews, it seems to me those reviewing this place don't like the taste of steak because Bobo's puts so much seasoning on their meet, I could have been eating anything.  Both my wife and I felt everything from the fillet, to brussels sprouts to the twice baked potato just had way too much salt and seasoning.  Similar with the steak, if you blind folded me I would have had no idea I was eating brussels sprouts because they were covered in so much crap.  

Within the booklet that the check came in, there was a pamphlet touting the why Bobo's steaks were so good.  I wish  I would have read this first because if I had, I would have known this place is a fake steakhouse.  Touting "corn fed beef" tells me you are using cheap beef that is fattened on feed lots off of the I-5 and yet charging me $50 for it.  When will people realize that this is the lazy man's way to raise cattle. 

I will say the service was very good, but when if someone asks where they should go for a steak dinner, I will not say Bobo's.  In fact, I wouldn't be able to recommend Bobo's.

Details:

Wife - Surf and Turf
Me - Petite Fillet
Shared - Brussels Sprout & Twice Baked Potato
author: Christopher C.

description: The drippings on the crab pan needs to be bottled and sold.  Seriously Bobo's??  Seriously!?!?!??
author: Tony S.

description:
OMG!!! BEST STEAK EVER!
That Bone in filter is ridiculously juicy and tender.

Highly recommend the Yellowtail carpaccio as well.
If you don't mind getting dirty over dinner, try their crab!
author: Hang E.

description:
This place has the best steaks out of all the Bay Area place i have been to. I have been here 20+ times, and always ready to go back again at a moments notice.

Lets start with the bread, I think it speaks to the attention to quality of this restaurant. It is just delicious, i'm not recommending you fill up on this, because the food is great but definitely have some to warm up your stomach, it's warm, butter, and soft, everything you want out of good bread.

I have had the bone in filet, the new york, the bone in new york, pretty much every steak they serve (except for the petite filet, for obvious reasons). You honestly cannot go wrong with a steak here. Every steak manages to taste even better than i remembered from the last time, a feat not easily accomplished by most restaurants. To live up to your  expectations and memories. A+ all the way.

I used to only have steaks here for the longest time because this is a steak restaurant after all, but recently, i started trying out their seafood selection too, to my shock, it is also... great. I know i sound like a fan boy to this restaurant but everything here is just so good and flavorful. When i eat seafood here i usually go with the crab and mussel or crab and shrimp on a skillet. The mussels and shrimp are good, but it's really the crab that sets this place apart. I would highly recommend getting something with crab from the seafood menu if you are going to get seafood here. Remember to have the crab over a skillet, for reasons I don't understand, it tastes better over a skillet, maybe it's the way they prepare it as appose to when they prepare it in the surf and turf. 

This place is perfect for every occasion, night out with the guys, birthdays, dinner with the girlfriend, everyone i have brought here before loves this place. Never had anyone tell me this place was anything but excellent.
author: Bennie H.

description:
Best of the Best!

Dry aged bone in fillet, with wine. Also great sides, and dessert. Staff is great, attentive and friendly. I would make reservations if you want to have a seat.  

This is my death penalty meal, oh wait....can you have wine on death row???
author: Jack H.

description:
I JUST got  back from dinner here for the first time and the food here is incredible! My boyfriend and I had gone to Peter Luger's Steakhouse in NY just last month, and we were groaning about how we couldn't find a steakhouse that compared on the West Coast. Boy were we wrong. Let me tell you about our meal!

First, my boyfriend meticulously read all the Yelp reviews, so we came to the restaurant expecting subpar decor, delicious filet mignons, and yummy olive bread. When we walked to the restaurant, the outside looked unassuming, and the inside looked like Buca di Beppo. But all that didn't matter because as soon as we were seated, I liked how the table we were sitting at was just the right size to hold food, but it wasn't so large that I felt like I was sitting miles away from my boyfriend. We were in a small room with a large party to our right, but the corner we were sitting in managed to still shelter us from the loud noises so we could have a comfortable conversation. Our waiter was very nice and smiley, which is always a plus. I like that we were given carafes of water on our table that we could pour ourselves.

Now enough about the place, let's get to the food! We ordered the olive oil loaf, the tuna carpaccio, two bone-in filet mignons (based on Yelpers' suggestions!), and two sides, one of the sweet yam, and one of the mod mac and cheese. Can I say INCREDIBLE!?

1) Sourdough olive oil loaf: Four thick slices of warm bread soaked through with olive oil and covered in chopped olives. This is probably the best bread I've had in a restaurant. The flavor was unlike any I've ever tasted. The inside of the bread was soft, warm, oiled but not overly oily, tasty, and comforting. The outside was fresh and had a satisfying crunchiness.

2)  Tuna carpaccio: Thinly sliced tuna, thinner than some other restaurants I've had carpaccio at. The slices were covered in minced chilies and a delectable sauce that was tasty and rich. This dish had us swooning in anticipation of the rest of the meal, we were so surprised at how good this was.

3) Filet mignons (bone-in): These steaks were amazing! I ordered mine medium, since I'm normally used to medium rare but the waiter said the meat closer to the bone would be extremely bloody if I didn't order medium. My boyfriend ordered his medium rare. The steak was comparable to Peter Luger! It was so delicious because of the way it was slightly crispy/charred on the outside, and tender/juicy on the inside. The sauce had a unique/distinct flavor and it was satisfying. My boyfriend said that his steak, especially the part closest to the bone that was bloody, tasted almost like the Kobe beef at Alexanders.

4) The sides: Mod Mac & Cheese and the sweet yam dish. The mac and cheese didn't have the traditional macaroni pasta, and the cheese was not your typical American cheese. This dish was so scrumptious and covered in bread crumbs. The yam dish wasn't anything special (tasted like yams) but was surprisingly well matched when eating it with the steak.

I'm glad to have found such a great steakhouse. This is going to be the one steakhouse my boyfriend and I will go to a lot!
author: Katherine P.

description:
Bobo's is one of the best places for steak in San Francisco.  The atmosphere is unique and warm, the beef is aged, all the food is delectable, and the service is great, too.  If you make it here (which you definitely should, no excuses!), I recommend the bone-in Fillet Mignon.  The crabs were also excellent, and so was the lobster soup (if you like curry).

If you're in San Fran, give this place a try!
author: Paul R.

description:
I know people come here for the steaks, but as a potato lover I was amazed by their twice baked potato.  Lordy Lordy Lordy...it was flavorful and delicious.  I'm not sure what they put in that thing, but it's different than other baked potatoes I've had.  Slightly spicy and definitely yummylicious.  I would come back just for that!  At the same time I enjoyed their filet mignon.  It was tender, juicy, and well marinated.  For dessert, I enjoyed the dunce cap chili chocolate.  Yeah weird name, but you won't regret it if you love chocolate.

I came back for the 2nd time...okay, I H-E-A-R-T their steaks!  If I was on death row, I would request Bobo's steak with their twice baked potato as my last meal.  AHHH...heaven.
author: Angie K.

description:
Yes, Bobo's can be pricey with the a-la carte options... but overall, phenomenal, phenomenal food from appetizers to dessert.  Cocktails were meticulously crafted with unique combinations and exotic liquors.  Extensive wine list, simply grouped by the bottle (at varying and simple-to-scan price points) or by the glass.  Best steak (hands-down) in the city... aged 6 weeks and served medium rare with an intoxicating buttery sauce.  Distinct ambiance free of touristy or chain-restaurant feel (albeit a bit too crammed and noisy with large parties and booths upstairs).  Be sure to ask for a secluded table or one with a view of Lombard. 

Selection for the evening 2 persons (all highly reccommended):
Drinks - Moscow Mojito and The Basil Martini 
Appetizers - Blue cheese wedge salad, lobster bisque/chowder
Main Course - Petite filet and surf and turf paired with Hess Cuvee blend and Perelli Minetti Cab
Dessert - Chocolate bomb with port
author: Rachel A.

description:
This place is for MEAT EATERS ONLY!!!  I am a slender girl and I don't eat meat often.  But there are times when I am starving, and I begin to feel a primal urge surging up from within my soul.  The kind of urge that can only be satisfied by ripping into the juicy, tender flesh of a COW.  Vegetarian casserole?  No thanks.  Grilled mahi-mahi?  Give me a break.  

Everything I ate at this restaurant was scrumptious.  If you have never been here, you must order the bone-in filet.  It's huge.  I could only finish about 1/3 of it.  I loved my mashed yam side dish.  I also loved my caesar romaine wedges.  This place is worth every penny you will have to pay.  I would plan on spending $80 per person without alcohol.
author: Kandi K.

description:
I am usually not a steakhouse fan, where heavy handed use of salt/butter, breathless descriptions of the steaks' preparation/cooking and expense accounts usually abound.  In contrast Bobo's felt like a neighborhood restaurant and had really tasty, well-seasoned dishes.  Butter was still in full effect, but wasn't used as a substitute for real cooking. Having just returned from Argentina, I thought I knew a few things about good beef.  However, I had the bone-in filet mignon and it was one of the most flavorful, tender cuts of meat I've ever had.  Ceasar salad and sides (twice-baked potato, baked yam, sauteed spinach)  were all decent , but this place is all about the meat and the huge cuts leave little room for anything else. Service was relaxed and didn't have any of the clubby, faux pretension of other stakehouses.  And dishes were plated on on fun art deco place settings.

Would recommend Bobo's for a guys night out or as a good place to take older relatives from out of town.
author: Kevin G.

description:
Started the evening with a smack to the face.  Well the night started with my brother passing the bar, but having me tell my parents that he didnt.  Hence the smack to the face from my mom. HAHA

This restaurant was the celebration dinner.  I think the food was great, just great.  I got the filet mignon on the bone.  Yum.  Haha, finished every bite of it, including the twice baked potato, the portabello mushrooms, and the zuccini.  

Service was very attentive, not to mention she was really cute :-p
Decoration was creative, very creative and had a very homey but elegant feel.  Although you're table is still within a close vicinity of the others guests, you don't really notice them.

My second trip here for my birthday last year, I was extremely disappointed at the service, food quality and not to mention drunk woman barfing.
author: Omar L.

description:
OK, my bone in fillet was good--not terrific, our Hamachi starter was too Ponzu-ed up, and our onion ring side was greasy as hell--couldn't eat them. However, the twiced baked potatoes were great. My GF had a petite fillet, and it was way petite--almost a Scooby snack for sure. 

A bit underwhelming to say the least, and the the jerks sitting next to us made it even worse. I really did not care how many lap dances he had before he nailed the stripper--although I doubt he actually did score. 

We won't be hurrying back, but I will say the complimentary parking rocks.
author: Deborah S.

description:
Food is really good, but plan to "break bread" up in here.  Only bring a date here AFTER you've "done the deed"...and you plan on sticking around...


Yeah, I really said that.
author: One Black Mans POV.. ..

description:
One of the best steaks I've ever had.  I didn't even know you could dry age beef for 6 weeks, but that really makes the difference. If it's your birthday, it's a great place to get fed.

HOWEVER, DEMAND A BOOTH OR EAT AT THE BAR!!!
We got stuck for a bit at a table that was like eating at a shoebox.  I asked for a booth and they accommodated.  Made the meal much more enjoyable I tells ya.

1.  Olive and garlic topped fresh baked sourdough bread loaf, with olive oil butter.  Awesome but a bit hard to tear apart without getting oil on your hands
2.  New York Strip, Bone In.  I actually picked up and gnawed the meat off the bone after I had finished it since nobody was looking.  I gotta say one of the best I've ever had.  

San Francisco has very few good steaks, but this is it man.
author: matthew w.

description:
I know this place gets rave reviews, but I don't understand the hype.  

I took my parents there for my dad's birthday.  We were seated promptly and the server was friendly.  However, I was slightly put off when my parents ordered sodas and they brought out the 10 oz coke bottle with a glass of ice.  I felt like that was more like being at a casual, order-at-the-counter type restaurant.  Then they brought out all our meals, but my brothers.  We had to wait another 3-5 minutes or so for that.  I can get that kind of service at the local TGI Fridays.  The steak was excellent, but I was completely unimpressed with the side dishes.  My brussel sprouts had so much oil, butter, and cheese on them that they could have been cardboard for all they tasted like sprouts.  I also ordered the wedge salad.  The blue cheese dressing was great, but it was tiny and lacked any other toppings unless you wanted to pay extra.

At these prices, I didn't feel this restaurant lived up to the class and food standards of similar grade venues.
author: Amanda H.

description: I have a couple of friends who have raved about this place, so it's been on my list of places to try for a while.  I finally made it to Bobo's to check it out, and man am I glad I did.  I grew up in the Midwest and had some damned fine steak growing up, but I've never been all that impressed with any place I've tried here.  But Bobo's is different.  It's a pretty small place, and my friend (who was visiting from Philippines) and I were seated upstairs at a table for two behind a bit of a curtain, so it was really quiet and great for conversation and catching up.  And the food was incredible.  We started with the crab cakes, which were quite good.  Admittedly, not the best ones I've ever had, but still very good.  For the mains, my friend got the petite filet and I ordered the bone-in filet.  Cooked medium rare, it was so tender and flavorful.  Yum, yum, yum.  For sides we got the brussels spouts and the modern mac and cheese, both of which were delightful.  Our server, Duy, was great as well.  Very friendly, attentive to what we needed without being overly present, and simply did a great job.  It's certainly not an cheap place to eat, but I don't mind paying for an excellent steak.  I'll definitely be back!
author: Dave B.

description: Bone in filet mignon is a must!  Crab is good too, but we come here mainly for the beef.  Excellent service and excellent food. This place get packed on weekends, so make sure you make your reservation in advance.
author: Char C.

description:
we started with the mussel appetizer served on a sizzling cast iron plate.  the flavors of the wine, butter, and garlic complimented the mussels.  the two boys both had bone-in  filet mignon, and i had the petite filet mignon.  they dry age their steaks which give them a flavor unique of their own, and they really do melt in your mouth.  we shared a couple of the sides, and the stellar picks out of the lot were the twice baked potato and brussels sprouts.  i have to say, i'm not one for brusels sprouts, but however they prepared it had me reaching for more.

my only gripe was that my petite filet mignon was barely a third of the size of the regular order.  i would suggest to pay the $10 difference, get the bigger portion, and take away any leftovers.  

service was attentive and on point.  valet is complimentary.
author: Sheri N.

description:
Bobo's Streakhouse is the worst restaurant I have ever been to in my life. They did everything POSSIBLE wrong. We made reservations by phone and upon arriving were told our reservation was not in their system - and then ignored. FINALLY the manager came out himself and apologized and seated us - the only worker here that was worth ANYTHING at all. The waiter was pathetic. He seemed confused and unhappy and had no personality to speak of. Our steak came out drenched in salt and tasted horrible, which we mentioned to the waiter with a "oh, ok". COME ON!

On top of all this the price was rediculous. Its like $80 a person to eat here. WOULD NEVER GO BACK and highly recommend anyone else to not give this place your business.

By the way this is not a one time fluke - I work at a nearby hotel and got many complaints about this place. I went before I knew...and boy I wish I did. I want my money back.

Update 4/1/12:

This place seems to be a hit or miss. I should know from the nearby hotel experience I used to work at. Some people would swear by this place and even fly in and stay at the hotel JUST to go to Bobo's. Other guests would come back ranting about Bobo's (as was my experience). I still stand by my 1 star because that is the experience I had, but I think the people leaving 5 stars probably really had a 5 star experience. Nonetheless, for this price range, its gotta be great EVERY SINGLE TIME. Am I right or am I right!?
author: Ken S.

description: Truly the best steak, I've ever eaten.  Bone-in-filet, medium, please!  I will be returning here.  I also enjoyed the brussell sprouts and mojito I had.  Service was above average.  The food truly speaks for itself at this place.  The atmosphere is quirky but quaint.
author: Trish G.

description:
Well. I could give them a better review. 

What should I say...

Interior--was interesting and playful
Server--nice and polite
Drink--I always order mojito, it was OK-I have had better ones
Steak--well...this was a little surprise, I usually order petite and usually it is enough for me. However, Bobo's petite was VERY SMALL when I saw mine and compared to my bf's.....I lost my words...
YES, I still was VERY hungry afterward. 


So if you probly should stay away from petite...
author: Sisi W.

description:
Last Meal on Earth....

Garlic Baked Sourdough olive loaf
Yellowtail Tuna Carpaccio
Triple order of Mussels
Caesar Salad w/ Pt. Reyes Bleu Cheese
Baked yam (Tasty but not spectacular)
Sauted Spinach 
Filet Mignon Bone-In (14 Oz of Heaven on Earth)

Pear Tartlet w/ Vanilla Bean Gelato

The space isn't really conducive to large parties.  The last time I was in we were a party of 12 and they seated us downstairs, much to the chagrin of the couple who were looking for a more intimate setting. If you're extremely lucky you'll find Ms. Swan behind the bar.  I've never had any service issues here but that is because MS is a part of my 14** family and she has always looks out for us. Try one of her signature cocktails. The Basil (a Ketel One martini with fresh basil and lime) is a crowd pleaser. Also ask her about the Ezy Rider!
author: Mingus R.

description:
BFME.

Best filet mignon ever. 

In my opinion Bobo's filet easily trumped Harris'. Ambiance is a little more quirky and fun at Bobo's too (as opposed to Harris' old school mafia look and feel). 

Decent wine list with all the basic reds, delicious crab cakes and REALLY good oily bread. Only regret was being too stuffed try to try dessert.

Oh, and I loved that our euro waiter kept calling Dave C. and I "boys."

"How's it going boys?"

"All set boys?"

"Have a good night boys."

Totally cute.
author: Derek B.

description:
Now I've had some steaks in my day in many places like NYC, Chicago, Kansas, St Louis, Oklahoma, Texas, Minnesota, Nebraska, and the list goes on just like that Cash song.

By far the best Steak I have ever had!
author: Eric n.

description:
This is a fun place.  Unlike the overly-priced swank you'll find at most steakhouses in the downtown area, you get what you pay for here.

Is it the best steak in the world?  No, that's Peter Luger in Brooklyn, but it's still very good.  You can't go wrong with the bone-in filet.  This place is reasonably priced and also has great seafood.  The sides are also well done for the most part.  You also get what you pay for with their ridiculously strong drinks!

My one complaint is that the tables are entirely too close together in some spots of the restaurant.  I see couples having their anniversary all the time in this place and they're forced to sit literally 18 inches away from the next table.  Everything about this place is intimate as far as lighting and ambiance, but then you have tables packed together like sardines.  It's a little odd, but I don't knock off points for petty things like that.  The food is good and the price is right.
author: Jeff S.

description:
I'll get to the point, the steak is delicious.  Get the filet mignon bone-in and you wont' regret it.  The dry-aging business adds a lot of flavor so it doesn't taste like you're eating semi-raw cow, it's semi-raw cow with seasoning!  

It's damn pricey though, can't they throw in some sides for that much? 

The atmosphere is campy and the side dishes are ok (you gotta pay extra for these).  Stick with the semi-raw cow with seasonings and you'll be just fine.
author: Shyam P.

description:
I ordered the surf-and-turf (crab legs with filet mignon) with sides of sweet potato. The main dishes are just under $20 and sides are about $8 each. The portions are on the slightly small side, but the excellent rich food seems to make up for it. 
Also my waitress was very pleasant and helpful.

On the neg, the two-person tables were a bit too small. Otherwise solid, though pricey. Definitely a good place to take out-of-town steak lovers for their masters in steakology. 

Behind my table, one of the waiters had accidentally spilled red wine over the customer's steak. The waiter offered to redo his steak, but the customer claimed that he liked it that way. He probably left a fat tip and went home happy. The steak is that good.
author: Jae K.

description:
Food was delicious, but what got me pretty PO'd was the lack of quality service. Service goes a long way for me, so I'm sad to give Bobo's 3.5 stars. 

My sisters and I came a few minutes early than our scheduled reservation. Because one of my sisters was below the legal drinking age, we declined to sit at the bar. The hostess (blonde hair with a pompous demeanor) then made us wait by the door and ignored us for the rest of the time. None of the other servers offered to help either. Weird thing was that the restaurant was not even packed, there was barely anyone in the dining area. 

It took about 20 minutes for our server to get to us. The bus boys were more helpful than she was. I think she came by a total of three times. Once to take our order, when we had the birthday cake and when we had to chase her down for our check. Tsk tsk.

Good thing the food was marvelous. The Petit Filet was cooked to perfection - rare, just the way I like it. The Hawaiian Sunfish was AWESOME - the seaweed was amazing, soy flavored was not powering but complimented the dish with enough saltiness. The sides were also DELICIOUS. Twice baked potato, grilled portobello mushrooms, crab cakes, and tuna carpaccio were impressive.

Would I come back here again? Mm... probably if I knew the hostess and server were different people.
author: Teresa Y.

description: Still the best steak in the city!!  Start with the Seafood Combo which includes Shrimp, Mussels and Crab Legs.  Next up is the Bone in Filet ordered medium.  Don't embarrass yourself with ordering any other steak on the menu.  Finally get some sides that look good, so weird but the onion rings are delicious here.
author: Tom W.

description:
mmmmm..... bone-in filet mignon... need I say more... I have been hooked on bobo's for about two years now.  Have had consistently great service, and even better food - - minus the one time I went there and they were out of the bone-in  :(  when you get there make sure to ask if they have it, and if not... walk on...  cuz you gotta get the bone-in... 

FACT: I have NEVER had to use a knife on my filet there....   yep.... that's how filet mignon is supposed to be.... Now you know.... 

FACT: Boys, if you want a "lucky" night, take a lucky lady here... :)
  
Decor: ummmm... UNIQUE.  There we go!!!  Just another good reason to bring a hot date to stare at instead....
author: Nora O.

description:
I was in town for the weekend and hunting for something to do with my ex (aside from the obvious) so as we drove around the city, the black and red valet sign caught my eye.  We drove up in his Grand National and headed in totally unprepared.  He was in a sweatshirt and jeans and I was similarly sartorial and we were both reservationless.   The maitre di would have none of that and promptly accomodated us with a great table in the bar by the window. The food was amazing.  This was truly the best steak I've ever had in my life. The atmosphere was joyful and romantic, and also very fun. The service was impeccable and the waitstaff was were incredibly, incredibly delightful.  I've been recommending it to all of my friends and we will definately be back and next time we'll get reservations! 

The food was so good that I sent them an email thanking them the next day for the great dining experience.
author: Traci G.

description:
I took my lady here for valentine's a little while ago.  It was excellent.  Here's why:

1.  Filet Mignon, BONE-IN

2.  The crab is so good you want to reorder it three times before the steak arrives.  It is sweet and good and whatever is on the shell is sticky and delicious.

3.  On a valentines day, we got an awesome booth with a view of the street (granted it's Lombard).

4.  The service was top notch, especially since I look like I'm 15 and rarely get the respect I would like at restaurants such as this.  

5.  I like steak, and lots of it, so I ordered the porterhouse (big boys only).  It was perfect. 

If I could afford to eat here on a daily basis, I would.  Nothing would ever get old.  Perfect for a date, for a group of friends, for taking Dad out and buying him dinner for the first time, or just going in by yourself and sitting down to a feast, alone.
author: Charley B.

description:
Last night (Thurs, June 5th) was my dad's birthday.  Per his request for a good piece of meat, I decided to call my friend Adam for advice.  Adam knows his quality meats and he immediately recommended Bobquivari's (Bobo's).  So I call and make a reservation for 7pm hoping that my piss poor planning (its 5:50pm when I call) won't result in a "sorry, we have no reservations for tonight" reply.

The hostess who answers is nice. She takes my name and confirms the 7pm reservation.  Afterward, I pull up Bobo's review on yelp and notice that there is complimentary valet (nice).  I read a couple of reviews and then start getting ready.

We get there at 6:50pm, valet the car, and I ask the hostess if we can get a nice booth since it's my dad's bday.  After a quick search she tells me she can help and leads us to the 3rd floor where we are seated at a booth looking out on Lombard Street (nice).  We open our menus, place our orders, and sip a nice merlot while awaiting our food.

My mom hates meat so she orders the double mussels and crab.  The rest of us order the bone-in filet mignon with the twice baked potato, portobello mushrooms, and crab cakes as sides.  Her seafood is first to arrive and all of us are shocked at the portion size which amounts to a 20 ' x 12' sizzling platter piled high with at least 60 mussels and 1/2 a crab!!  Immediately afterward our dry aged filets are served and the conversation ends as we arm ourselves with forks and knives to get down to business.  

The filets are delicious- with a great flavor reminiscent of a steak I had in Florence.  The mussels are a bit dry but very tasty.  The crab has an excellent flavor.  The crabcakes....wow (perfectly crispy on the outside and moist inside).  The twice baked potato seems to be a hybrid of a baked potato and mashed potatoes (yum!).  The portobello mushrooms are fresh tasting and not too salty.

Overall, we got more than we had expected and are already planning our next birthday dinner!!
author: Russ N.

description:
I sit here getting hungry again conjuring up thoughts of Boboquivari's. My friends took me here for dinner this past Friday and damn was it a good dinner.

Bobo's is located right off Van Ness. It's on the right side right after you turn left onto Lombard, so be careful you might miss it.  We got our car valeted (complementary) and walked inside. You know, I never understood why steakhouses are always dark and look like antique shoppes, and Boboquivari's is no exception. They got this creepy carnival decor that makes you wonder if the clowns are gonna spring to life and climb off the wall.

We sat down and got our bottle of wine cracked open ($15 corkage fee) and enjoyed a fine cabernet as we looked over the menu. My friends ordered the surf and turf, which is a half crab and petite filet while I ordered the bone-in filet mignon. For sides we ordered twice baked potatoes as well as the sauteed portobello mushrooms. For starters we had crab cakes.

The waitress brought out our crab cakes and some bread. The bread had a great flavor to it, but it was wayyy too hard. It was like eating a giant crouton. Crab cakes had this cranberry relish that I think had some fried shallots in it. Very good. Not 14 dollars good though.

At last, the entrees were brought out. Prior to ordering, the waitress informed us that the steaks were dry-aged. Lovely. I've always wanted to try some dry-aged steaks. Basically the meat is left alone in a temperature controlled environment for 6 weeks and the natural enzymes and shit break down the fibers. Something like that. Shit was good though.

We all ordered our steaks medium-rare which is the only way to have a steak. When I plunged my knife into the huge piece of steak and carved out a bite size piece and placed it in my mouth, I felt this overwhelming sense of euphoria. After each bite, alternating between the mushrooms, chugging the wine, and back to steak I kept wondering if the portobello mushrooms they gave me were "special". The clowns really did come to life but instead I greeted them with open arms... no that didn't really happen. Basically - the steak was really good.

My friends enjoyed their crab and steak, but I can't really say if they had a psychedelic experience like I did eating their food. One felt that it wasn't enough food and the other said they were just satisfied.

Overall, everything but the steak was alright. The bone-in filet that I had deserves 6 stars. So in total, 4. Next time I come here I'll just order the filet...twice.

Recommendations: anything on the menu that has cow.
author: John B.

description: Best steak I've ever had. Ambiance is delightful and the service spot on. An instant favorite.
author: Kylie S.

description:
Let me tell you about our disappointing Christmas Dinner.
First,I got my salad before my husband got his cocktail
Next,the second I finished my salad (which was good),we
got our meals(which was very rushed)
next,the meal,my steak was good.My husband's was terrible
The sides both sucked as well as that dried out bread(YUCK)
So let's say all in all,A HORRIBLE EXPERIENCE>NEVER AGAIN
author: Jane M.

description:
I notice that most of the reviews that downgrade Bobo's, mention price.   I am not sure what price has to do with a good business establishment.  If it's good, it's good.   The Filet Bone In, is awesome.  And if you have the appetite you can try and tackle the Porter.  The porter includes a New York, and a Filet which are cooked separately; but delivered together.  Unbelievable.  

And I've read the comnparisons of Bobo's to more economical steak houses.  This is not a very good comparison.  That's like comparing the cost of grape juice with wine.  Bobo's steaks are dry aged, while 99% of the other steak houses wet age or non-age. A steak that's dry aged for 4-6 weeks tastes better than a wet aged steak because flavors stay intact in a dry aged setting better than a wet or non-aged setting.  More flavor, means better steak.  

My suggestion for first time goers.  "The Bone In Filet" .  Mark it down.  It's a lock.
author: Chad C.

description:
My quest to find the best steak in San Francisco finally ended a few years ago at this fine eating establishment.  It looks fairly unassuming from the outside, and the inside makes you feel like you're in a quirky, swanky, circus-tent themed bar & grill, but don't let that throw you off.  Not only is this one of the best steaks I've ever had, but the appetizers and sides are delectable (get the mussels, and the twice baked potato), and when the bone-in fillet or NY arrives, you feel like you're in heaven, at least I do.  The steak's flavor is awesome, and it melts in your mouth.  Phenomenal steak.  Check out their website if you want to get a feel for how they marinate/prep their steaks...they're serious about making a seriously succulent piece of meat.  

This place is rather pricey, (especially since the sides are a la carte) but believe me, it is worth it.  They have valet parking so no issues there.

In summary, best steak in SF = Bobos!
author: Zach J.

description: I had a wonderful experience @ Boboquivari's! I loved everything about this place from the decor-food-lighting-employees.,etc. I had the filet and it was the best steak i've ever had. It was so soft and basically melted in your mouth, I didn't even need my knife. I also had the twice baked potato which was the jumpoff. I tasted a few other sides like the modern mac-n-cheese and brussel sprouts, both were tasty and above average. We had some bottles of cabernet, very nice and decently prices. It takes about 2 hours because they don't rush but I promise it's worth the wait. My gf had the shrimp and crab combo and it was fantastic. They provide you w/ free toasted bread that has garlic oil based taste to it. I'm a fan . The restrooms and private and have a classy feel. I'll be back next time i'm in the city.
author: Evan N.

description:
Took my hubby to this place for his bday. Filet mignon, crab and crostini were delish but the side dishes were too salty and overcooked (swiss chard, twice-baked potato & onion rings). Server started out well but completely fell off. My water glass stayed empty for 20+ minutes and it was 35-40 minutes between our appetizers and entrees. I couldn't event get our waitresses attention because we were tucked in a weird, tiny corner booth. 
Our salads came with the entrees and sides so there was no room whatsoever on the table. When I'm paying prices like Morton's and other nice steak houses I expect excellent service and delicious food all-around. While we're happy we tried this place, it's very doubtful we'll be back...unless someone else is paying and we have 3 hours to dine! Honestly we're not too surprised, as we've found San Francisco service standards to be ridiculously underwhelming compared to other cities.
author: Julie E.

description:
I came here with no real expectations since I had not really heard much about it prior, but it was recommended by a friend who has been giving us great recommendations for food, so I didn't doubt it would be a good meal. I called ahead to check what the parking situation was, but I was half way thinking that I would have to find street parking of pay for vallet. I was pleasantly surprised to hear that they have complimentary vallet. YES! No need to search for parking! We got there and handed over my car to the vallet and walked to the front door. I was expecting this place to be a big place, since all the steakhouses I have been to are fairly large places. When we walked into the place there was a bar and some tables hugging the window on the left side, then there was another small room that our hostesses lead us into to be seated at our table and that was it. The small little room had at most 8-10 tables only. Its crazy how small this place is, but that means that we would not have to flag any waiters or waitresses down, big plus. We ordered the house salad, Bone-in Filet cooked medium rare (chef's recommendation), twice baked potato.

Garlic Loaf Bread - very warm, soft and nice texture. They drizzle extra virgin olive oil over the top of the bread. We tried it like that and it was very flavorful, but we asked for butter anyway, because Butter is awesome. I must say, I took a liking to the bread here because I couldn't stop eating it. No Atkins diet here, haha.

House Salad - Nice light salad. They toss the EVOO vinaigrette in a separate bowl and then plate it so there is no puddle of vinaigrette at the bottom of the plate, but every piece of salad is nicely coated. Very good.

Twice Baked Potato - WOW! I usually don't like baked potatoes too much, but this twice baked potato is wonderful. I suppose you can't go wrong with how they make it. They first bake the potato, then scoop out in insides of the potato, make mash potatoes, while adding zucchini, chives and fontina cheese, pop it back into the shell and bake it again. When it comes they hit it with some sour cream and chives on top. Whats not to like?

Bone-in filet(medium rare - no messing around, the plate arrives with the filet centered on the plate with sauce surrounding. First bite, toasted butter sauce hits my palate and it's beautiful. The next thing I realize is the silky soft filet meat. The aging process they use here to prepare their meats is first rate. It's aged 4-6 weeks in a special offsite facility. That is some good stuff. There is no way you can replicate this process at home or even at other steak places. Wow, what a combination

Chocolate Dunce Cap Cones - chocolate chile mouse filled mini wafer cones. So good. The chile in the chocolate mouse gives it a nice little kick. Don't worry the heat is very subtle and its more in the background and plays a great supporting role.

I wanted more after the meal, not because I was hungry, but because I wanted more of the divine bone-in filet. Why is the steak so good here? Its the dry-aging process they use. They dry-age the steak for 4 to 6 weeks in a large, specialized facility under the watchful eye of a highly-skilled butcher. Wow! This place cares about their steak...a lot! 

This is at the top of my list for steak. To quote my friend who recommended this place, "I will come here any time for any meal."

Salud!
author: Michael W.

description:
Absolutely amazing! 
The mozzarella starter - perfect ... slightly cooked so just melts in your mouth ... served with the sweetest little tomatoes and stunnign chorizo ... mmmmm! 
The fillet Steak .... perfect ! - tasty, succulent ... the jus divine !!!
The twice baked potatoes ... this is my new favorite thing ! My mouth is watering just thinking about it ... perfect ! 
The deserts .. oh my!!! 

Overall absolutely frigging brilliant! 

Im going back .. soon ..... please .... mmmmmm!!!
author: Amy W.

description: I couldn't focus, everything was over salted. I wanted to rinse my steak and veggies in my water glass.
author: Anna L.

description:
The best steak I've had in San Francisco. SF has been lacking a proper steakhouse, and we still don't have one considering the La Foundue-esque jester/Prague/clown/1649/renaissance-style decor (La Fondue is in Saratoga if you want to look up the review).

However, we now have steak that is up there with the likes of Peter Luger, and one of my recent favorites, Mastros City Hall (Drinkwater) in Scottsdale. Harris's, thank you for serving us for so long, but there's a new dry-aged steak in town (and they dry-age it for longer, which is what they say is the key to the wonderful taste and texture).

Melts like butter in your mouth. While a bone-in filet is a rare treat, I'd actually recommend the regular filet, or the porterhouse to get a taste of bone and filet without sacrificing anything (they cook the pieces separately).
author: Mike G.

description: Amazing food, one of the best steak houses in SF...top 3. Bone in filet is the way to go. Order some sides as well, they do not disappoint.
author: Matt Z.

description:
The bone-in filet mignon truly tops all. You simply cannot find a better steak anywhere (famous last words). My guests and I were floored. The waiter actually asked, "How is your steak?". As if he ever gets a response other than a giggle followed by [insert gushing adjective].

The sides were surprisingly good too. We sampled some and found them all really good: Cauliflower (!), Baked Potato, Onion Rings. 

The wine selection was good as was the coffee. We didn't have room for desert.

The service was very good. Friendly and attentive.

The restaurant itself is nice. It's one part "kind of weird" and nine parts classy. Yes, it has stuffed jesters and odd things here and there, but nothing too over the top.

Be sure and take advantage of the complimentary valet parking. Parking in that area of town can be tough, or at least irritating.
author: Andrew M.

description:
My expectation was just too high since one of my friend advertise Boboquivari's with lots of praise and promise like "It is way better than any other steakhouse!" and "the good thing is.. It's inexpensive!" (pardon me?)

Ok, it might not that pricey for a steakhouse, but seeing that the portion was waaaaay too tiny and the crab was flavorless *oily too*... Somehow it's not worth the price. 

This place is kind of packed that you could feel suffocated inside, distance between each table are SO close...makes the ambient gone, since you can clearly hear others' conversation that is only 30cm far. Definitely not the best place for special occasion. 

Another downside is parking. As always in San Francisco, usually if I finally get one, there will be a joyful moment with confetti everywhere...NOT ! because I've spent an hour desperately & hungry..and in the end I just saw its Valet Parking sign in front of the restaurant. Great.
